Cerita Warga Bekasi Terpaksa Pakai Air Sungai Tercemar untuk MCK
03 Nov 2019, 14:16 by Antara, Ninis Chairunnisa
TEMPO.CO, Bekasi - Warga Desa Sukaraya, Kecamatan Karang Bahagia, Kabupaten Bekasi terpaksa melakukan aktivitas mandi, cuci dan kakus atau MCK di Sungai Cilemahabang yang diduga tercemar limbah perusahaan. Kondisi air sungai tercemar itu berwarna hitam dan mengeluarkan bau tidak sedap.
"Mau gimana lagi, kemarau menyebabkan pasokan air bersih minim. Air bersih di sini hanya cukup untuk masak aja saat musim kemarau panjang gini," kata salah satu warga, Masrikoh, 39 tahun, Sabtu, 2 November 2019.
Menurut Masrikoh, pencemaran di sungai ini sudah relatif parah. Dari informasi sejumlah tetangganya, sungai ini sudah tercemar limbah Bahan Berbahaya dan Beracun atau limbah B3.
Meski begitu, Masrikoh bersama para ibu di desanya mengaku tidak memiliki pilihan lain. Mereka tetap mencuci di tepi sungai yang kini tenar disebut warga dengan istilah sungai hitam karena perubahan warnanya itu.
"Jadi mau tidak mau setiap hari kita tetap cuci baju di sungai hitam ini, dikucek nanti sampai rumah dibilas lagi," kata Masrikoh.
Berdasarkan pantauan Antara, bau menyengat tercium dari sungai yang menghitam itu. Diketahui Sungai Cilemahabang berhulu pada Sungai Cikeas, Bogor dan tergabung pada kanal Cikarang-Bekasi-Laut yang menyatu dengan Sungai Cileungsi hingga akhirnya bermuara di Tarumajaya.
Warga lainnya, Sarman (63) mengaku awalnya Sungai Cilemahabang memiliki air yang jernih. Bahkan setiap harinya selalu digunakan warga untuk mandi. Namun sejak tercemar, banyak warga yang tidak lagi menggunakannya untuk mandi.
"Kalau terpaksa ya ada saja yang mandi. Pernah waktu itu ada yang mandi jadinya gatal-gatal. Mana airnya bau pesing. Pakai sabun juga tetap saja bau. Ini sudah lama kayak gini," kata Sarman.
Kondisi tersebut membuat warga setempat kesal. Bahkan mereka menyampaikan aspirasi kerinduan akan sungai yang bersih lewat sejumlah spanduk yang dipasang di bantaran sungai. "Kami minta pemerintah daerah segera menangani pencemaran ini jangan tinggal diam saja," kata Sarman.
Sementara itu, Ketua Komisi III DPRD Kabupaten Bekasi, Husni Thamrin mengatakan pihaknya sudah meninjau kondisi sungai tercemar itu dan berjanji akan menelusuri asal penyebab pencemaran. "Kami akan panggil Dinas Lingkungan Hidup untuk menyelesaikan persoalan ini. Kami menduga ada perusahaan nakal yang sengaja membuang limbah ke sungai, akan kami panggil juga mereka," kata dia.

Story of Bekasi Residents Forced to Use Polluted River Water for MCK
03 Nov 2019, 14:16 by Antara, Ninis Chairunnisa
TEMPO.CO, Bekasi - Residents of Sukaraya Village, Karang Bahagia District, Bekasi Regency are forced to carry out bathing, washing and latrine or MCK activities on the Cilemahabang River that is suspected of being polluted by company waste. The polluted river water conditions are black and give off an unpleasant odor.
"It can't be helped, the dry season has caused a lack of clean water supply. Clean water here is only sufficient to cook during the long dry season," said one resident, Masrikoh, 39 years old, Saturday, November 2, 2019.
According to Masrikoh, pollution in this river has been relatively severe. From the information of a number of its neighbors, this river has been polluted by hazardous and toxic waste or B3 waste.
Even so, Masrikoh along with the mothers in his village claimed to have no other choice. They continue to wash on the banks of the river which is now well-known by residents as the black river because of the change in color.
"So like it or not we keep washing our clothes every day in this black river, then we can wash them until the house is rinsed again," said Masrikoh.
Based on monitoring by Antara, a pungent odor is emanating from the blackened river. It is known that the Cilemahabang River is tipped on the Cikeas River, Bogor and is incorporated into the Cikarang-Bekasi-Laut canal which integrates with the Cileungsi River until it finally empties into Tarumajaya.
Another resident, Sarman (63) claimed that initially the Cilemahabang River had clear water. In fact, every day the residents always use it for bathing. But since it is polluted, many residents no longer use it for bathing.
"If you are forced to, someone will take a shower. At that time someone took a shower and itched. Where the water smells of urine. Even soap is still smelly. It's been like this for a long time," Sarman said.
These conditions upset local residents. They even expressed their longing aspirations for a clean river through a number of banners posted along the riverbank. "We ask the regional government to immediately handle this pollution, not to remain silent," Sarman said.
Meanwhile, Chair of Commission III of the Bekasi Regency DPRD, Husni Thamrin said that his party had reviewed the condition of the polluted river and promised to trace the cause of the pollution. "We will call the Office of the Environment to resolve this issue. We suspect there are naughty companies that deliberately dump waste into rivers, we will also call them," he said.
